summary: This is a letter from the U.S. Attorney's Office to Judge Alison J. Nathan regarding the case United States v. Ghislaine Maxwell. It transmits the parties' joint request to charge and proposed verdict sheet, noting redactions and the submission of an exhibit under seal. The letter details procedural steps and legal justifications for handling sensitive materials.

persons.name: Alison J. Nathan
persons.context: Presiding judge in the case United States v. Ghislaine Maxwell, to whom the letter is addressed.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: The accused in the criminal case referenced (20 Cr. 330 (MN)).

persons.name: Damian Williams
persons.context: The United States Attorney for the Southern District of New York who submitted the letter.

persons.name: MIE
persons.context: Assistant U.S. Attorney who signed the letter on behalf of Damian Williams.

connections.description: MIE is an Assistant United States Attorney acting on behalf of United States Attorney Damian Williams in submitting this court filing.
Judge Nathan is the presiding judicial officer over the criminal case against defendant Ghislaine Maxwell.

events.title: Submission of Joint Request to Charge
events.description: The U.S. Attorney's Office files a joint request to charge and proposed verdict sheet with the court in the Ghislaine Maxwell case, including redacted and unredacted versions.

locations: United States Courthouse, New York, New York 10007
keyFacts: The document is a procedural filing in the criminal case United States v. Ghislaine Maxwell (20 Cr. 330).
The Government submitted redacted and unredacted versions of a joint request to charge and proposed verdict sheet, with redactions justified to protect a third party's privacy under legal precedent.
An exhibit (Exhibit A) from another, non-public case was submitted under seal in relation to a defense comment.
The defense's objections to the proposed charges are reflected in redline text and comment bubbles within the documents.
